pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:0.5: 84. The training rule on precious things
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:1.1: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:1.2: a monk was bathing in the river Aciravatī, when a brahmin, too, came there to bathe. He deposited a bag with five hundred coins on the ground, bathed, forgot about the bag, and left.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:1.3: The monk thought, “This is the bag belonging to that brahmin; it wouldn’t be good if it got lost,” and he picked it up.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:1.4: Soon the brahmin remembered. He hurried back and asked that monk, “Sir, did you perhaps see my bag?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:1.5: Saying, “I did indeed,” he gave it to him.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:1.6: The brahmin thought, “How can I avoid giving a reward to this monk?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:1.7: And he said, “I didn’t have five hundred coins, I had a thousand!” And he seized hold of that monk.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:1.8: After being released, that monk then went to the monastery and told the monks what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:1.9: The monks of few desires complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:1.10: “How can a monk pick up precious things?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:1.11: “Is it true, monk, that you did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:1.14: “… Foolish man, how can you pick up precious things?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:1.15: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:1.16: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:1.17.1: ‘If a monk picks up something precious or something considered as precious, or he has it picked up, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:1.18: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:2.1: Soon afterwards they were holding a celebration in Sāvatthī, and people went to the park all dressed up.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:2.2: Visākhā Migāramātā, too, left her village for the park all dressed up.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:2.3: She thought, “What will I do when I get to the park? Why don’t I pay a visit to the Buddha?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:2.4: She then removed all her ornaments, bound them in a bundle with her upper robe, and gave it to her slave girl, saying, “Listen, take this bundle.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:2.5: Visākhā then went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:2.6: And the Buddha instructed, inspired, and gladdened her with a teaching, after which she got up from her seat, bowed down, circumambulated him with her right side toward him, and left.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:2.7: And the slave girl left too, forgetting the bundle.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:2.8: The monks saw it and told the Buddha. “Well then, monks, pick it up and store it.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:2.9: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:2.10: “Within a monastery, monks, you should pick up precious things or what’s considered as precious, or have it picked up, and then store it with the thought, ‘Whoever owns this will come and get it.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:2.11: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:2.12.1: ‘If a monk picks up something precious or something considered as precious, or he has it picked up, except within a monastery, he commits an offense entailing confession.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:2.13: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.1: At that time the householder Anāthapiṇḍika had a whole village working for him in the country of Kāsī,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.2: and he had told an apprentice there that if the monks arrived he should make them a meal.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.3: Soon afterwards a number of monks were wandering in the country of Kāsī, when they came to that village.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.4: When that man saw them coming, he approached them, bowed, and said, “Venerables, please accept a meal from Anāthapiṇḍika tomorrow.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.5: The monks accepted by remaining silent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.6: The following morning, after getting various kinds of fine food prepared, he had the monks informed that it was time for the meal. He removed a ring from his finger and then offered the food to the monks, saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.7: “Venerables, please leave after you’ve eaten. I’ll go to work.” And he left, forgetting his ring.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.8: The monks saw it and said, “If we just go, this ring will be lost,” and so they stayed right there.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.9: When that man returned from work, he saw the monks and said to them, “Why are you still here?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.10: And the monks told him what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.11: Those monks then went to Sāvatthī where they told the monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.12: who in turn told the Buddha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.13: After giving a teaching, the Buddha addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.14: “Within a monastery, monks, or inside a lodging, you should pick up precious things or what’s considered as precious, or have it picked up, and then store it with the thought,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.15: ‘Whoever owns this will come and get it.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.16: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.17.1: ‘If a monk picks up something precious or something considered as precious, or he has it picked up, except within a monastery or inside a lodging, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:3.18: If he does pick up something precious or something considered as precious, or he has it picked up, within a monastery or inside a lodging, he should store it with the thought, “Whoever owns it will fetch it.” This is the proper procedure.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.1.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.1.6: a pearl, a gem, a beryl, mother-of-pearl, quartz, a coral, silver, gold, a ruby, a cat’s eye.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.1.8: whatever people consider valuable or useful—this is called “considered as precious”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.1.9: Except within a monastery or inside a lodging:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.1.10: apart from within a monastery or inside a lodging.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.1.12: if the monastery is enclosed, then within the enclosure. If the monastery is unenclosed, then in the vicinity.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.1.14: if the lodging is enclosed, then within the enclosure. If the lodging is unenclosed, then in the vicinity.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.1.16: if he takes hold of it himself, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.1.18: if he gets someone else to take hold of it, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.1.19: If he does pick up something precious or something considered as precious, or he has it picked up, within a monastery or inside a lodging, he should store it:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.1.20: after taking note of its appearance or distinguishing marks, he should store it, and then make an announcement: “Whoever has lost something should come.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.1.21: If anyone comes, they are to be told, “Describe your goods.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.1.22: If they succeed in describing the appearance or distinguishing marks, it should be given to them. If they do not succeed, they should be told, “Keep looking.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.1.23: If the monk is leaving that monastery, he should first place it into the hands of suitable monks there.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.1.24: If there are no suitable monks, he should place it into the hands of suitable householders there.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.2.2: if he picks up something precious or something considered as precious, or he has it picked up, within a monastery or inside a lodging, and then stores it with the thought, “Whoever owns it will fetch it”;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.2.3: if he takes hold of something considered as precious on trust or he borrows it or he perceives it as discarded;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.2.5: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc84:4.2.6: The second rule, the training rule on precious things, is finished.
